data.text: Strong Kickstand for Loaded Touring Bike

Can anyone recommend a bicycle kickstand that can handle a loaded, heavy bicycle? I have been through three and I'm about to lose hope. I've tried the stick but I'm not the biggest fan of this solution. Thanks in advance!
One wheel trailers act as stands when set at 90â€¢

data.text: Not always practical, okay out of town but on a pavement?

data.text: Use a walking pole
data.author: Andrew Dunn

data.text: Never bothered me not having a kickstand, I suppose of you e nothing to stand the bike against when repacking it could be an issue
data.author: James C Openshaw

data.text: Pletscher/ESGE twin leg kick stand.... Not the cheapest but I find that it works really well.
data.author: Steve Toczyski

data.text: Second vote for pletscher but I use this one. The advantage I find with this one is that it has two clamping points thereby reducing the strain on the chain stay. The rubber foot is essential on anything other than hard ground. Sure they weigh a bit but For sheer convenience they can't be beat.
data.author: Michael Cope
Michael Cope

data.text: Great in stability, convenience and also handy when lubing the chain, since the cracks can freely rotate. The rubber piece is not super long lasting. Buy two. I did find a plastic one which has a bigger surface so it can handle a looser underground, and is more rugged, lasts longer. BTW as a photographer I want to be able to be ready for action as soon as possible. That is why my bike has a frame lock, fastest way to have it parked on a slope.
data.author: Erik van den Boom

data.text: we use this kick stand. Fits well and takes the weight. One has snapped at the leg and needs replacing. I take this as good sign that the clamping system work.
data.author: Ginette Corr

data.text: I tried many stands before the pletscher. None of which really made the grade. I've had mine for around six years now and aside from the problem of really boggy or soft ground I'd rather have it than not.
data.author: Michael Cope

data.text: Broke 4 of them in my 11k tour, none of them withstand the load
data.author: LaurenÈ›iu Macovei

data.text: Pleased with this one
data.author: Birte Ph

data.text: Double kickstand is the way, with a wide base. They can serve as portable bikestands, too, if they raise the back wheel enough ! I have the Hebie and am very satisfied.
data.author: Steven Brooks

data.text: Do you have a plate for a double kickstand, or just a single?
data.author: Stephen Cieply

data.text: Defiantly a double leg type and here in Kenya all the delivery bikes use as seen here, but the delivery motorbikes use a 'carrier to floor' leg. another thing I do on my heavy bikes is to drill a small hole right through the head tube so you can lock the forks with a small rod, about mudguard stay size, it makes the bike much more stable when parked and is another anti theft device.
data.author: Phil J Handy

data.text: Good ones are heavy! Resist the temptation and carry on without. Every gram counts when cycling uphill.
data.author: Mark Verleye

data.text: I would suggest a strap to secure the front wheel and Fork from turning and rolling that is your betrayer
data.author: Craig Cartner

data.author: Simon King

data.text: I went through the same and decided against one as they generally don't do well when your fully loaded and easily tip. What I do reccommend is getting a sunglass strap around your lower handlebar and when you stop loop it over the brake and pull tight (pic below on my gravel bike) this will stop your bike rolling and falling over when leant against something. I have one on every bike, just choose one with a pull that has some resistance, or make your own with a spring lock/cord toggle ðŸ™‚ Just don't make my mistake, on a few occasions I forgot about it and tried to cycle.. once went about 3 miles couldn't understand why I was struggling ðŸ™‚ Also something that thieves don't notice straight away if they try and ride off :-)
data.author: Renyk de'Vandre

data.text: Yes, as others, the Pletscher rear stand.
